thread.title: Apartment building proposed for Dogtown

author: Tim Bryant St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: Apartment building proposed for Dogtown
text:
Rendering of apartments proposed for 6300 Clayton Apartment building proposed for Dogtown Handout 
Rendering of apartments proposed for 6300 Clayton 
A developer wants to construct a five-story apartment building on a vacant Dogtown lot where a similar proposal four years ago produced neighborhood opposition. 
The plan announced in January 2013 was for a five-story building south of Forest Park at 6300 Clayton Avenue. Developers behind the plan got the necessary zoning variance project but were unable to proceed. 
Pearl Companies , of Indianapolis, is behind the new proposal for the site formerly occupied by a lumberyard. Brad Richey, a company principal, said Friday that he was aware of neighborhood opposition to the earlier plan. His company’s proposal includes garage parking and commercial space, elements lacking in the previous plan, he said. 
Pearl’s $20 million proposal is for 100-market rate apartments, compared with 63 units in the earlier, failed proposal. 
The new proposal includes nearly 15,000 square feet of ground-floor commercial space that would probably include a restaurant. Garage parking would fill the remainder of the floor and an underground level with 123 parking spaces. Richey said Pearl had the site under contract. 
He said Pearl’s project would have a different appearance than the earlier proposal even though St. Louis architect Joe Klitzing designed both. 
Klitzing’s design for Pearl includes a broad sidewalk on the Clayton Avenue side of the building and a garage parking entrance around the corner on Graham Street. 
Pearl representatives are scheduled to present their plan next week to members of the Clayton-Tamm Community Association. The neighborhood meeting is set for 7:30 p.m. Thursday at St. James the Greater School.
